SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Feeling out of sorts, fatigue, and lightheadedness.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts, fatigued, and lightheaded for the past five weeks. He denies any fever or chills but reports feeling bloated occasionally. He has been taking his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. The patient admits to struggling with his diet recently due to home renovations and eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath with exertion and a slight cough.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

VITALS

All vital signs are within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm, 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

1. Congestive heart failure: Fluid retention.
2. Hypertension: Well-managed.

PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure:
   - Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day.
   - Weigh daily and report weight gain or shortness of breath.
   - Order another echocardiogram.
2. Hypertension:
   - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   - Continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report elevated readings via patient portal.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow the treatment plan as discussed. Contact the clinic with any concerns or new symptoms. Await further instructions after test results are received.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right knee pain. The onset of her pain began yesterday after she stumbled and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall from a ladder. She denies any other injuries. The patient reports pain on the inside of her knee. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to provide relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation in lower extremities.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left knee reveals no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but everything else appears to be lined up properly.

ASSESSMENT

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have recommended conservative treatment in the form of a knee brace and temporary use of crutches for the next couple of days. The patient will follow up in one week to assess progress, and if not improved, an MRI will be ordered. I have prescribed Motrin 800 mg every six hours with food for pain relief, with a two-week supply.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain after lifting heavy boxes.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He presents today with lower back pain after lifting heavy boxes on Saturday. He heard a pop when lifting and experienced pain, which improved after lying down for an hour. The pain has been persistent since then. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used Icy Hot, but these provided minimal relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon. He finds it difficult to find a comfortable sleeping position but lying on his right side helps.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Diabetes type 2
Hypertension
Osteoarthritis

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys taking long weekends for vacations.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Metformin
Lisinopril

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Denies chest pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, or chills.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Constitutional: Elderly Caucasian male in no apparent distress.
Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

VITALS REVIEWED

Blood Pressure: Elevated at the office visit.

RESULTS

Diabetes Labs: Hemoglobin A1C elevated at 8.
Back X-ray: Normal, good bony alignment, no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Back pain - Lumbar strain from lifting.
   - Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity.
   - Referral: Refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2 - Elevated hemoglobin A1C.
   - Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day.
   - Follow-up: Repeat hemoglobin A1C in 6 months.

3. Hypertension - Uncontrolled.
   - Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis - Stable, no further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports a relatively stable mood with adherence to Prozac for depression management. He has been struggling with hypertension control, particularly on weekends when he may forget to take his medication. He denies any significant shortness of breath or cough, but experiences some chest pounding during morning runs. He also reports nasal congestion due to pollen.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath or cough at rest, but reports chest pounding during exertion.
• ENT: Nasal congestion due to pollen.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• ENT: Pain to palpation of sinuses.
• Extremities: No lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression: Patient is doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily. Continue current regimen and provide a refill for the medication.
2. Prior lobectomy: Patient is exercising regularly and has no significant respiratory complaints. No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed at this time.
3. Hypertension: Blood pressure is well-controlled in the office today. Encourage the patient to continue taking medication regularly, even on weekends. Order an echocardiogram to further evaluate the systolic ejection murmur.
4. Nasal congestion: Likely due to pollen. Recommend over-the-counter antihistamines or nasal corticosteroids as needed for symptom relief.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue Prozac 20 mg daily and Norvasc for hypertension. Schedule an echocardiogram. Utilize over-the-counter medications for nasal congestion as needed. Follow up through the patient portal for lab results and echocardiogram findings. Call the clinic with any questions or new symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents with right finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her finger got caught and bent backwards. This occurred on Sunday. She has tried icing the finger and taking ibuprofen, but the pain persists. The pain is worse with movement.

The patient also reports a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Appendectomy at age 18.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right finger pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Endorses constipation.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. Pain with flexion. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right index finger: No fractures, normal alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right finger pain after a skiing accident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's x-ray shows no fractures, and her physical exam is consistent with a contusion at the tip of her right index finger.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. Provide an aluminum foam splint for the affected finger.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to use the splint and take the prescribed medication. If the pain does not improve within a week, advise the patient to return for a follow-up visit.

Constipation.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is currently taking Miralax for constipation.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Miralax as needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient reports feeling fatigued, feverish with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.
• Psychiatric: Endorses anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

MEDICATIONS

• Ferrous sulfate 325 mg twice daily.
• Over-the-counter Vitamin B12.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of anemia and has been taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12. She had a hysterectomy in 1996, so heavy periods are not the cause of her anemia.
• Additional Testing: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered. We will also recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 325 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption.
• Specialist Referrals: We will send a referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instructed the patient to take her iron pills with orange juice for better absorption and to follow up with the hematologist.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today with a history of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any trouble with headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable. Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where a pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. The patient reports bumping into door frames recently.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient denies any significant past medical history.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient is married and works as a computer programmer. He denies any history of alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drug use.

FAMILY HISTORY

The patient is adopted and has no knowledge of his biological family's medical history.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CONSTITUTIONAL: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
NEUROLOGICAL: Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.
EYES: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's MRI findings and discussing the symptoms, surgical intervention is recommended to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa. The patient will be referred to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to assess peripheral vision before and after surgery. The patient will also be scheduled for a transsphenoidal surgery to remove the pituitary adenoma. Risks and benefits of the surgery have been discussed with the patient, and he agrees to proceed with the surgery.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with the eye doctor for a visual field test and will be scheduled for surgery. The patient is advised to call if he has any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of chest pain and difficulty swallowing. The onset of her pain began in early October 2020 and lasted for four days. The patient describes the pain as sharp and located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone. She reports that the pain was worse with eating and she had difficulty swallowing during that time. The patient went to the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, but all results were normal. She has not had any chest pain or swallowing issues since that time. The patient was going through a stressful job transition at the time of the symptoms.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Cardiovascular: Reports chest pain (resolved).
Gastrointestinal: Reports difficulty swallowing (resolved).
Psychiatric: Reports anxiety related to job transition.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No other abnormalities noted.

ASSESSMENT

Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. Suspect the patient had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, with possible contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

PLAN

Discussed the option of an EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of Smith-Magenis Syndrome and kidney function.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days, weighing 4 pounds, 8 ounces. She has had issues with feeding and regulating her temperature but has been improving. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen a GI doctor, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist. The patient's mother reports that Katherine has around 8 to 10 wet diapers in a 24-hour period and drinks a good amount of fluids.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Smith-Magenis Syndrome, feeding difficulties, temperature regulation issues, reflux.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant in the family.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Lives with her twin sister and mother in Dallas, Georgia.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Katherine is a well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. She has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT

Smith-Magenis Syndrome with potential congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract.

PLAN

1. Obtain a kidney ultrasound today to screen for any abnormalities.
2. If the ultrasound results are normal, no further follow-up is needed. If abnormalities are found, schedule a follow-up appointment at the town center location to determine the next steps and future follow-up.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient's mother will be provided with instructions for the ultrasound and will be contacted with the results.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. The patient reports that her right wrist started to hurt severely and became swollen. She denies any previous injury to this arm. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Positive for mild tingling in fingers.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: No carotid bruit, no murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: No lower leg edema, palpable pulses.
Right wrist: Obvious swelling and ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation throughout, bony crepitus, pain on flexion, extension, radial and ulnar deviation, able to make a fist but not tightly.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a right wrist Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively at first with a brace and pain medication (50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours). We will schedule surgery as soon as possible, followed by physical therapy 3 times a week after surgery. The patient will wear the brace for approximately 6 weeks. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in a month to assess the patient's progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 1 month.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a 50-year-old male presenting with right knee pain following a slip and fall accident one week ago. The patient reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced pain and swelling in the right knee since the incident. He has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief and swelling.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Employed as an x-ray technician.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and swelling.
• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the right knee: Pain to palpation on the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion.
- X-ray: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

1. Right knee MCL strain.
2. Hypertension.

PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain:
   - Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling.
   - Provide a knee brace for support and healing.
   - Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
   - Encourage elevation and rest for the affected leg.

2. Hypertension:
   - Continue 20 mg of lisinopril.
   - Refer to nutritionist for dietary management.

The patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan. All questions were answered to the patient's satisfaction today.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a patient who presents with left shoulder pain for approximately three weeks. He is unable to recall any specific injury but has been active and working on renovating his basement. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol couldn't manage. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which provides some relief but not complete resolution of pain. No numbness or tingling reported.

PAST HISTORY

None mentioned.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Active lifestyle, currently renovating basement.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not mentioned.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Extra strength Tylenol.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.

Neurovascular exam: Capillary refill less than three seconds, sensation intact to light touch.

X-ray results: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

1. Order MRI for left shoulder to rule out any other issues.
2. Refer patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks.
3. Continue Tylenol as needed for pain relief.
4. Consider steroid injection if symptoms do not improve after physical therapy.
5. Schedule follow-up appointment after completion of physical therapy.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow the physical therapy plan and schedule a follow-up appointment after completion. Call the clinic with any additional concerns or if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports occasional left knee pain that occurs less than once a day while walking. The pain comes and goes quickly and does not last long. Patient has not experienced any injury to the knee and has not taken any medication for the pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

VITALS

Temperature: 98.2
Pulse: 72
Respirations: 16
Blood Pressure: 122/70

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Grade 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with occasional left knee pain, likely due to arthritis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily. Consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee and prevent further problems.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is currently stable.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports slightly elevated fasting blood sugar levels.
- Medical Treatment: Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess if adjustments to Metformin are needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly, a 53-year-old female, was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule. Biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma, and molecular testing is pending. She presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She reports a minimal cough, sore throat, and mild fatigue. No nausea or vomiting.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good family support and positive interactions with nursing staff.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

VITALS

Oxygen Saturation: Within normal limits.
Blood Pressure: Not reported.
Heart Rate: Not reported.
Respiratory Rate: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Chest: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- General Examination: No edema.

RESULTS
Imaging

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for possible surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (four times daily) to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue current chemotherapy and radiation treatment. Take prescribed medications as directed. Return for follow-up visit as scheduled.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is on metformin. No known history of immune deficiencies in the family.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient recently traveled to Zambia. Family owns a donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness or diarrhea.

VITALS

All vitals within normal range.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB WORK

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a low immunoglobulin A level, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other concerning symptoms.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of the deficiency and advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control. Informed the patient to notify healthcare providers of the deficiency if receiving blood products.
- Medical Treatment: Will order additional blood work to check other antibodies.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is on metformin.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and monitoring blood sugar levels.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports engaging in pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports pain in the inside of the right elbow, radiating slightly into the forearm. Denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow.

VITALS

Vitals are within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the right elbow: Moderate tenderness to palpation of the medial epicondyle. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality observed.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Medial epicondylitis.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with medial epicondylitis, likely due to overuse and potential damage of the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I explained the diagnosis and its relation to the patient's pottery activities. I advised the patient to rest the elbow, apply ice, and take ibuprofen for pain relief. I also recommended avoiding pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
- Medical Treatment: I ordered a sling for the patient to wear while awake, ice application for 20 minutes three times a day, and ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week.
- Follow-up: I scheduled a follow-up appointment in one week to assess the patient's progress.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a middle-aged male who presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports a recent fall while walking outside, but did not think much of it. The patient has a history of hypertension and has been prescribed Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc. He admits to missing doses occasionally and not adhering to a low-sodium diet. The patient has a history of smoking but has significantly reduced his intake.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies any significant pain or injury from the fall.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 128/72, other vital signs within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
• Lower extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure (CHF) and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's recent chest pain, shortness of breath, and trace edema are likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient was counseled on the importance of taking medications consistently, adhering to a low-sodium diet, and monitoring weight.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Consult with a nutritionist for dietary guidance. Obtain a renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan and will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT:

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe when present. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. The patient has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father).

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:

Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea and vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Kidney stones

FAMILY HISTORY:

Father had kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAM:

Abdominal: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS:

CT scan of the abdomen shows a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

1. Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).
- Medical Treatment: Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, to be alternated with Tylenol. Provide a urine strainer for the patient to catch the stone when it passes.
- Diagnostic Tests: Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
- Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If symptoms persist, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. The patient first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The initial blister has since become unroofed, revealing soft, mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient has been on antibiotics for six days, with some improvement in symptoms, but the wound has turned black around the edges and the patient has developed calf cramping and red streaking up the inside of his calf muscle. The patient also reports difficulty catching his breath and a cough in the last two days.

The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher in the last two weeks, with a recent A1C of 6.7. The patient has been compliant with diabetic shoe and insert usage and has been checking his feet regularly.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Respiratory: Positive for cough and difficulty catching breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for calf cramping and pain in the right foot.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythema. No bony exposure. Foul odor present.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS

Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on his right foot.

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a necrotic wound with cellulitis and erythema, likely due to tight shoes and uncontrolled blood sugars.
   • Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
   • Medical Treatment: Perform debridement in the office, obtain a culture, and consider different antibiotic therapy based on culture results. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely. Follow up in 7 days.
   
2. Diabetes management:
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood sugars have been trending higher recently, and tight glycemic control is essential for wound healing.
   • Specialist Referrals: Follow up with the endocrinologist to ensure continued A1C control below 7.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee tick bite.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a 60-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of a tick bite on his right knee. The patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. The tick bite occurred over a week ago and has been causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever, chills, joint pain, and difficulty moving his knee. He has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease. Since the tick bite, he reports feeling generally unwell and experiencing headaches.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain.
Neurological: Denies numbness in the right knee.

VITALS

BP: 122/70, HR: 67, Temp: 98.4

PHYSICAL EXAM

HEART: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.
LUNGS: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
RIGHT KNEE: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance over right patella, pain to palpation, full range of motion.
SKIN: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT

1. Possible Lyme disease due to tick bite and presentation of right knee.
2. Hypertension - well-controlled on Lisinopril.
3. Diabetes - blood sugars in the 120s, on Metformin.

PLAN

1. Start Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for three weeks for possible Lyme disease. Order Lyme titer and Western blot tests to confirm diagnosis.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.
3. Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to assess kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
